reviewText:
Twilight Struggle is widely considered to be one of the best boardgames of the last decade (it’s ranked #2 on the Board Game Geek website) and this software version absolutely does it justice. Follow the tutorial, then play a game or two and you'll find the interface to be very intuitive, allowing you to easily examine your cards, test each play option, and execute your decision quickly. Watch the video above to get a good feeling for how things work.

Multiplayer is asynchronous, allowing you to create games with various chess clock time limits from 30 minutes all the way up to 45 days, for those who want to play just one move per day. There’s a chat function in both the multiplayer lobby and each game. The friends list is not connected to Steam, but specific to your Playdek account, which is required for multiplayer and shared amongst all their games. If you’ve ever played Ascension, Agricola, or any of the other Playdek iOS games you can use the same account. Rankings use the standard ELO system.

Singleplayer is still a work in progress in the initial release: it's a challenge for less-experienced players, but not Twilight Struggle veterans. Also, expect to wait 10-20 seconds for the A.I. to take each turn. Playdek says the single player A.I. is learning from every game played, so it should get better as time goes on. Right now it's a great way to learn some strategies to improve your multiplayer play.

The game is cross-platform Mac/PC, and it'll also be cross-platform with the upcoming iOS and Android releases, so you'll be able to play other folks no matter their choice of gaming device.

Playdek has added some nice touches like audio clips of cold war era leaders and other period-appropriate sounds that help set the mood. Sound effects are easily turned off if you don't like them. You can also increase the interface speed once you know what's going on and don't need time to read the cards as they’re played.

The game interface scales well. I’ve played in on an 11” MacBook Air up to a 40” UHD desktop display and everything’s looked good.

I highly recommend Twilight Struggle for both the veteran tabletop player who’s looking for more opportunities to play, and for the newbie who wants to check out one of the best boardgames there is. I’d never played Twilight Struggle before this and now I can’t stop.

Rating: 4.5 out of 5.  5 stars as soon as the A.I. is better and faster.

reviewText:
This is an interesting 1v1 game with a pretty steep learning curve. The rules and cards aren't hard to comprehend - it's just that there are lots of them to memorize, and games are pretty long with lots to keep track of.

The games are decided by 3 things: skill (most of which is experience/memorization), card-drawing luck, and dice-rolling luck.

This game is less about strategy/simulation and more about probability-based calculation that relies on memorizing lots of events. The computer does help you see the probability distributions and visualize moves before committing to them so that finding good moves is easier. The interface is better as a result, but the actual game is still held back by being a board game.

The optimal move has little to do with analyzing the situation and making a decision based on strategy - it's about minimizing your vulnerability to predetermined events that will happen in the future based on fixed event cards.
For example, you have to avoid spending your moves building up a presence in Romania because there's a card that removes all your influence in Romania and gives it to your opponent. What makes Romania different from Bulgaria or Hungary? Nothing that actually matters in the gameplay rules or the map geography, and nothing that has to do with strategy or what the game is trying to simulate.

The basic problem is that the event cards are completely predetermined (seemingly inspired by actual historical events). When you make moves that seem like they should exploit a weakness or create different opportunities, the game doesn't generate new or different event cards. The game doesn't recognize that the situations which allowed those historical events to happen might not exist in your game. It's just a digital version of a board game that has hard-coded events.

Once you have memorized all those events, you can plan better and the game becomes more interesting. But there's still a huge luck component that will make the experience less rewarding and unnecessarily slow down the process of learning/improving.

I'm not sure how balanced the two sides are. There are some options to handicap one of the sides, so there's probably a workaround for potential imbalance.

It was a few hours of fun, so I'll recommend" it assuming the multiplayer works well

I'm a huge fan of Twilight Struggle and really appreciate the makers for creating the game. That said, I cannot recommend purchasing the digital version of this game in its current incarnation.

First, the AI is truly awful, it presents no challenge to a veteran whatsoever. If there were multiple difficulty options and this AI was ranked Very Easy then that would be fine. This AI couped the Phillipines with the China Card on the first turn... it boggles the mind. Would it really be so difficult to tell the AI to coup Iran instead? Iran is a much higher priority than the Phillipines. The AI also has a strange tendency to headline India-Pakistan War/Nuclear Test Ban on the first turn... when both India and Pakistan are empty and Defcon is at 5. A stronger AI would certainly headline something like Socialist Governments/Red Scare instead and use Nuclear Test Ban for Operations. It feels like whoever programmed the AI had no real understanding of how to play the game.

Now this issue with weak AI would be fine if the online mode was good. It's much more fun to play against humans after all. Unfortunately each time I've played online my connection to the game's servers has been consistently failing every minute or two, which makes the game unplayably slow and wastes tremendous amounts of time. My connection to my ISP is fine, I can browse the web and play any other online games just fine, but for some reason Twilight Struggle just can't connect to my internet. It's hugely irritating. The fan-made version of Twilight Struggle (hosted for free on chantry-games.com) could connect to my internet but for some reason this official version cannot. A fix for this issue would make the game much better

Now onto the positives. The music is great and sets the tone very well, makes me feel tense just listening to it. The visual design of the game is very appealing too and it's very easy to navigate the UI. The quotes from US and Soviet leaders at the start of each turn is a nice touch, though it would be better if it wasn't always the same quote - I'd like to hear more randomised variety.

TL;DR: You are getting one of the best strategy games of all time for $15 or less, when the normal board game version costs $40, and takes much longer to play than the digital version. If you like history even a little bit, or strategy games at all, I would highly recommend this game.


Twilight Struggle is an incredible game where every move feels like it could be your last, every mistake is paid for dearly, and every minor victory feels so, so rewarding. This game features a 1v1 tactical deathmatch between the US and USSR during the Cold War, and each side tries to best the other by spreading their influence throughout the world. Play is mostly card based, and each player must decide which cards to play each turn to destroy their opponent: but not all cards are helpful to you, and the threat of global nuclear warfare constantly looms over you. This is probably the most intense and fun strategy game I have played, and seeing it finally brought to Steam is a blessing.

PROS:
- One of the best startegy games ever. Not kidding. The strategic value behind this game is off the charts.
- I find the interface to be fairly good, save for a few hiccups
- There is a pretty good tutorial for any newcomers
- You can play online multiplayer or offline against an AI
- The game gives you several options for modifying the base game, if that's your style
- Atmoshpere, music, etc. is the best I could possibly imagine it to be for a Cold War strategy game like this
- Tons of historical references for any history nerds out there
- Considering the physical board game version of this is usually more than $40, and THAT price is worth it, $15 is pretty damn cheap
- Taking over the world and nuclear warfare are ALWAYS fun

CONS:
- This game has a pretty big learning curve, in my opinion. The tutorial is good, but you may have to play several games before you get the hang of things
- I have noticed several minor glitches, usually when trying to get past a certain screen or when trying to click something, but I have found none of these to be game-ruining
- May have to nag your friends to buy a copy if you want to play with someone you actually know
- The AI takes a bit of time to make moves

NEUTRAL:
- Not sure if I just suck, but the AI seems to be pretty brutally difficult. Some people may like this, others not
- This game does involve chance: picking up cards and rolling dice. Some people may like this in strategy games, other people might not


Overall, I would definitely recommend this game. 10/10 board game, 10/10 strategy game, 7/10 video game. You will have a lot of fun spreading freedom as Murica, and a lot of fun killing capitalist pig-dogs as the commies. Like I said, I think the asking price is not too bad. I would definitiely pick this game up on sale.

One of my all-time favorite boardgames by GMT has offically ported over to the PC. I couldn't be happier at the transition.

I've played a few games now of this version, more than I ever played of the boardgame, and I love how it has encapsulated the rules and dice rolls behind the scenes. Unlike the table top version, you don't have to double-check the rulebook to make sure you're adjusting influence or commiting a coup properly. And if you do have a rules question, simply click on the ? mark on the screen and it will pop-up a page with what you need to know based specifically on what you're trying to do.

Both GMT and Playdek have turned a remarkable table top boardgame into a wonderful PC version.

Now, if I could only win...

Is Twilight Struggle a Good Game??

Twilight Struggle is a good game, if you haven't played it before then the only thing you really should know is it takes a few games to memorise a few important cards and their ramifications to truly understand how to play. Even if you get a hand full of cards that trigger good events for your enemy, they likely have a hand of events that trigger your events, and having the optionto choose when your opponent events trigger is more powerful than it seems at first.

There is a palatable tension for both players as you try to figure out what your opponent is doing, which often leads to bluffing maneuvers and domino effects. The USSR player starts strong but weakens towards the end game. Despite this, the game is balanced well.



Is this a good application??

It allows you to play Twilight Struggle online, and doesn't do anything else spectacular. There are a few UI bugs such as setting resolution while in full-screen mode, but I was not prevented from changing any options after some fiddling.

The tutorial works but misses one or two key points. Annoyingly, if you try to make an illegal move, the game won't tell you why. You have to go read the played card to figure out what you're doing wrong.

The AI is smart enough to win the game in some interesting ways, but will occasionally do some really bad/non-sensical moves. In one game vs. the AI it didn't even play a card that would automatically lose them the game if held onto. Apparently it will improve later, but for now  I wouldn't treat the AI as anything but a way to learn the game before playing online.

Since there is nothing stopping you from playing Twilight Struggle on VASSAL essentially for free, the only reason to buy this is if you want to trade VASSAL's quirks for the official game (and it's quirks), nicer graphics and be able to find games easier.


TL;DR: Read the paragraph above, recommended because the game is good.

reviewText:
The physical version of Twilight Struggle is, without a doubt, my favourite boardgame. The reason for this is a simple but resolutive one: it is a thrilling game. No other game has got me grinding my teeth in agonising tension about what card to play, where to invest my resources, trying to outguess my adversary. Twilight Struggle is not a game, it's an experience.

The PC game takes the elements of the game to the electronic format and does a fair job in the technical aspects. The important thing, however, is that the game itself remains the same: choose a side (or not) and vie for global domination against the other superpower. You do that by using the cards in your hand, which reflect historical events of the Cold War such as 'the Cuban Missile Crisis', the foundation of the 'NATO', the establishment of the 'Warsaw Pact', etc. However, each card has also an associated point value that you may use to place direct influence on the countries, roll for realignments to change the influence balance in countries, or to throw a 'coup' to try to displace the enemy altogether.

Influence in the countries is key to score victory points (VPs): once you reach or surpass an influence threshold you get to control that country; control of countries reflects presence, dominance or control of a region, such as Europe, Asia, the Middle East or Africa and entitles each player to a certain ammount of VPs. But here's the thing: the scoring of regions happens through cards just as those of the events, so you never can be really sure when a certain region will be scored and must keep alert at all times.

The game has a steep learning curve at the start, since the players must get to know the cards in the deck to be prepared to face what may come. That may sound a bit appalling but it's the base of its mastery. I can only recommend this game as a matter of principle: you will like it if you like tension, unpredictability, second-guessing, and managing chaos. This is a game of starting fires that your adversary must put out while you try to put out the ones they start. It is a game of long term strategies and short term reactions. It is a game that rewards patience and resilience. It is a game that puts you under pressure and you better like it.

reviewText:
TWILIGHT STRUGGLE was the number-one-rated board game on boardgamegeek for something like eight years until it was dethroned by Pandemic: Legacy last year. Now it is number 2.

It is a game of Cold War brinksmanship and high strategy for two players or one player vs a pretty decent AI. You take the role of either the United States or the Soviet Union and the game begins in 1945, with the battle lines drawn between the liberal capitalist Western Europe and the Communist Eastern Europe and Asia. The goal is to use world events, coups, and political realignments to shift the governments of a region toward one bloc or the other. Controlling a region nets victory points; earning 20 victory points at any time, or having the most VPs at the end, wins you the game.

If you start Global Thermonuclear War, you lose. But sometimes there are immense temptations to walk right up to the razor's edge. It's a one-of-a-kind experience that puts you right into the ♥♥♥♥ed-up brain of a Cold War strategist, making choices that are completely logical and rational from a game theory point of view but are horrific when you stop to think about what they mean in the real world.

Will you change history? Or will you be buried by it? That's up to you.

The gameplay of the original boardgame is imported basically seamlessly into this adaptation. Like the Sentinels of the Multiverse adaptation, there are a few areas where you can kind of tell this was developed to work on touchscreen devices as well as PC - lots of big buttons and dragging things into highlighted areas - but Twilight Struggle's support for the PC interface feels a little bit more robust. You CAN play cards by dragging them around the screen or you can just click them and then click the menu option for what to do with them.

The interface is polished enough for a small-scale game. It's not bare-bones. There are fun little aesthetic touches, like the tap-tap-tap of Morse code when it comes time to confirm your turn, or audio clips made from famous speeches by Stalin, Truman etc when new turns begin. Eveyrthing seems to work so far.

I haven't tried the multiplayer yet, but the single-player works well. The AI isn't stupid; it's not like playing some kind of cosmic genius expert at the game, but it doesn't do obviously stupid things and it's a great way for beginners to learn the ropes. Also, the developers have apparently committed to constantly refining the AI based on the outcomes of games played out in the real world, so we can expect it to get harder and better as time goes on.

reviewText:
TL;DRA surprisingly well made board game, and I'm someone whose board games knowledge is literally absent. If you're willing to take some time to learn its mechanics and lose your first games, go ahead and give it a shot!

I have always been a strategy game fan and the Cold War is also one of my favorite history periods, so I simply had to buy this game once I noticed it on my steam recommended games page thingie on the store.
This is probably the first time that thing gets it right, because I'm really enjoying this game so far!

As far as I know, this is a digital port of a classic board game which was rated by several websites as THE greatest board game of all times, I'm not competent enough in the subject to say whether it is true or not, but I can say it is indeed a good game.
So, what do you do in this game? You play as either the USA or the USSR, and you basically have to spread and strenghten your influence throughout the entire world by putting influence points, attempting coups, activating historical events and partecipating at the space race.

There are three kinds of cards you'll be playing with: the USA cards, the USSR cards and the neutral ones.
Despite what you might be thinking right now, you can play EVERY card in the game, even if it is not of your side's!
Obviously, this'll lead to consequences; more precisely, the enemy card's event will be triggered if you use it, but you'll be able to use its points to do aforementioned stuff in the previous paragraph.

There are 10 turns, each turn is by itself divided into 7 rounds, and there are three periods: Early War, Mid War and Late War.
These periods can generally tell you who's going to prevail in each period's turns: the USSR will have a pretty huge advantage in the Early War, thanks to many event cards you'll be given whose effects are strong, the Mid War period will be even and then, in the Late War, the USA will get their good cards.

I'm not going to explain ALL the rules of this game (I kind of did, there just are a few more features left to be explained, but the tutorial imo is good enough at doing so), but I'm going to tell you it is a pretty addicting game.
This is not a game which can be played right off the bat unfortunately, you have to get accostumed to its mechanics and see which strategies are the best for each side, but once you do get comfortable with its settings, it is really worth it.

8/10

The Game Itself --

reviewText:
Crappy digital version of a great board game. It's seriously killing my interest in Twilight Struggle.

Chantry was free, much better, and it cut to the chase. The UI on this game is clunky, the tabs/map has poor choice of colouring, and you can tell this game was designed for a smartphone. It's good I haven't played it fullscreen, because I've heard the buttons don't actually work when doing so. Meanwhile, the buttons themselves look ugly, bulky, and they flash at you, along with the flying headlines that fly at you every time a round ends. They have too many confirmation processes which are unnecessary, such as the DEFCON reminder. Urgh. It's like they're marketing the game to 12 year olds. Just. URGH.

Additionally, the AI is terrible. It once gave Europe to me on a platter, then instead of preventing me from having more countries, it just wasted all of its points trying to break my controlled countries. I've read two accounts now where it chooses (on its first turn, on the first round) to coup the Philippines with the China card...what even...

Finally, considering they had a budget of nearly $400,000, I scratch my head to why this game only has 4 soundtracks (two of which are national anthems, they all loop every minute or less), which sound like they've been made on Guitar Pro 6? Seriously?

However, I will state the positives;
- I like the chance calculator for die rolls, and country counter for each continent. However, I don't even read these.
- The Game Log.
- The continent zoom buttons. Which I don't use either.
- I like how it keeps your W/L record.


Now, to speak of the online. Things the online is missing and requires;
- You can't watch other people's games. This needs to be available.
- You can't title the matches you create to describe what kind of game you wanna play. Infact the matchmaking interface looks fugly, and needs a rehaul; they can put it on the same page with the chatbox, for starters.
- They need to sort out its ranking system. I thought it was neat at the start, but then I realise it's not a real ranking system, and is unbalanced (not even depending who you lose to).
- They need a 'hardcore' mode, which doesn't tell you of which cards are redundant, which doesn't tell you that you need to hand in your scoring cards two rounds before the end of the turn, which doesn't keep a track of every card used, and which doesn't ask you to confirm every decision you make.
- Perhaps add tournaments.

reviewText: So far it seems well worth the wait. One of the greatest board games of all time and it's a faithful and good translation to a computer game. The AI is better than I expected, but an experienced TS  player will be able to handle it easily. I like the tutorial for new players, but this is one of those games that looks more complicated to learn than it actually is - a few games against the computer AI should get the average strategy gamer up to speed. The card/board mechanics that the game is actually based on are as good as ever; you must manage cards representing historical events that help one side or the other, and often to make a play you have to hand your opponent an 'event' that helps his efforts. That results in a real feeling of historical progression through the cold war and creates all kinds of problems for each side as they move through the game. At 15 bucks this is an excellent value for a game that never fails to absorb me every time I play it. Hoping a lot of new players are brought into the TS fold thanks to this well-designed PC version.
